All sands are hot and dry--all clays cold
and wet; and, therefore, the manuring san
dy lands with clay, or clay lands with sand,
is best, for this changes the nature OF the
land itself; whereas dung, and other substan-
ces, afford only an inferior and temporary
improvement. Mixed soils, which incline
to the clayey kind, are best for corn and
pulse. But 1t is not the natural soil only
that the farmer ought to consider, but the
depth of il. and what is Immediately under
meath it. For if the richest soil is only Sc
ven o. eight inches deep, aud lies on a cold
wet clay or stone, it will not b. 50 fruitful as
leaner soils that lie on better under STRAIT
um. Gravel is, perhaps, the best under
stratum to make the land prolific.


The best loans, and natural earths, arc
of bright brown or hazely colaur. Hence,
they are called hazel leans. They cut
smooth and tolerahle easy, without ctiHginh
to the spade or plough share; are ,iTAt, III
able, and fall into small clods without cda ~
ping or cracking in dry weather ui turning
into mortar when wet. Dark grey, and rus
set mould, are accounted the next best
The VOL St of all arc the light and dark ash
colour. The goodness OF land may also be
very well judged of by the smell and touch.
The best emits a fresh pleasant scent On be-
us hNS " lSi'HSiNNl hPt NoINAlilll aitNt
rain; and being just proportion Of sand and
clay intimately blended, will not stick much
10 the fingers on handling But all soils,
however good may be impoverished, and e
ven worn ont, By successive crops without
rest, especially if the ploughings are not
very frequently repeated before the seed is
4 suwn.


| IT we examine tracts of land " ich have
not been cultivated, we find nature has adapt
ed different kinds of plants to most Of the
distnguishable varieties of SOILS; and altho'
some belonging TO one, may from some
cause or other be found on lands of differ
ent quality, they seldom thrive, or perfect
their seeds, so as to become general, The
great care OF the farmer ought, therefore,
to be, by proper niHtnrcs, 10 reduce his
land to that state and temperament IN which
the extremes of hot and cold, wet and dry
are best corrected By each other; to give
them every possible advantage flowing from,
the benign influence Of sun and air; to adopt
such plants as thev afford in this state thc
greatest nouriShment TO; and 10 renew thcil
fertility by q judicious allowance of the NOS,
proper manurcs. Where these things art
done, there are few spots 50 untiitndi; te
cultivation as not to repay his expeHs 5 and
laJour with plentlful increase. But y tNput
these, the best tracts of land will in time Gc-
come barren waste, or produce htt.t hui


weeds.

monty thought to be; but horses are general
ly fond of it, and if allowed, would often eat
too much. 1t is supposed that saccharIne
matter is developed by the fermentation
which hay undergoes in the NOW, and as
that which is NOW burnt appears to contain
more saccharine matter than any other, 1t is
probable that it may be found preferable
where used with discretion, provided it has
not been too much heated; for when it has
become quite brown there will generally be
found considerable degree of acidty in it,
which probably would be injurious if eaten
freely. Hay that is dry and void of smell is
certainly bad; but that which is dusty, moul-
dy. and of bad smell is exceedingly prelu-
dicial. Dry hay should be moistened with
water and if at all dusty, should be previous
iy we'll shaken: this is particularly neccs-
sary when it is used for horses that are gree
dy of water or subject to coughs.-Hay at
ter 1t is one year old, rather becomes worse
than improves, particularly in small mows /:
after the second year, it should never be used
when any that is newer can be procured
perhaps good straw is preferable to 1t, espe-
cially if the horse is allowed good quantl-
ty of oats. Horses should be allowed either


a run at grass or green food in the Stable
during the early part of summer

FARM, Of about 65 acres situated in Millcreek
Hundred, Newcastle county, Del, about three
miles from Staunton, and eight from Whining
ton, of which about ten acres are wood land, and
the residue arabic, well set with orchard grass
and clover The Buildings are, good stone
dwelling house, 81 by "a feet, Two stories high,
gith three rooms on the first foor and four on
the second with good cellar under the whole
"a frame Barn, cellared under, 36by 80 feet
a Stone .Toiner's shop, and Comcrib, % by II
feet, and stone Smokc-house, all Of which are
nearly new and in good order. The quality
the land is well adapted for farming or grazing,
and has been well lined, it is in good neigh
bourhood, near several places ofpublc worship,
is in good neighbourhood for Mills, and within
two miles of good Limestone quarry. There is
likewise, a young thrifty Apple Orchard, and a
Peach Orchard, and the land is we'll watered
with good springs For further particulars en-
quire of JosrrH BRINGuuNsT, Wilmington, or on
the Farm, of JOHN FERRIS.

FxDerience has often demonstrated that
the most serious consequences may ensue
when horse is subjected to violent exer-
else ON full stomach. This indigestion
thus occasiened often causes violent chollcs
which sometimes prove fatal. Surgeon
White says" Il have known many instances
of this: and when we consider now often
post and stage-coach horses are suddenly at
tackled during their work with gripes OF
fret, as it is commonly termed, arising en-
tirely from this cause, it will appear aston
ishing that it has not excited the attention OF
post masters and other proprietors.


Oats, which escape being crushed or brok-
en- by the teeth, though properly soaked by
the saliva and Juice of the stomach, are not
properly digrsted. The following commu-
nication from an English officer in the SER
vice of the East India Company will sbew
the utility of brushing grain tor feeding
horses or cattle.


II have always been an advocate for cut
tinp hay and straw, and bruising corn (grain)
for cattle of every description, and am con-
yinced that any man, who has pad atten-
zion to the subject, will soon see the advant-
age that must result from the adoption of
that practice. My attention was partlcu-
lsrly called to this subject by circumstance
which came under my notice when with the
cavalry unQef Iluiu Lam, Oh VIZ "N'NN 80
banks of the Junna in 1904. Channa, the
usual food, being scantilysuppli ed, Lord
Like ordered the horses to be fed with
equal parts of channa and barley, bruised
and steeped in the usual way; but from the
irreyularity of the size of the barley and
ehanna. and nattention oil the part OF those,
whose duty it was to sec it prepared, the
greater part of the barley was given entire.
and passed through the stomach and lntes-
tines of the horses, apparently little, u al Az
IMPAIRED in it's nutrtive quality ne scar
citv of grain which prevailed at that time n
dnced MANY thousands to flock TO the Brat
isb camp. in search of food, and daily wit
ressed for many weeks together many hun
dreds of those people Of all ages; coming IN
TO the lines of our cavalry, and anxlously col
lecting and carrying away the excremeht as
Il fell from the horses. This they exposed
few hours to the sun, and by rubbing and
sitting it, procured a large supply of good
food. This detail, which is on son'e account
affecting to humanity will probably go fur
ther in convincing the incredulous upon this
.ubiect than the most ingenious theory. II
must prove to every unprejudiccd man that
a Drodigious waste takes place III the use o'
corn for horses when it is not previously
ground or bruised"


1t appears from the experience OF Mr.
Curwen a celebrated English agriculturist
that the feeding of working horses OF
cooked provender is highly profitable. One
great advantage, he observes is the shor
time that is required for eating prope,
quantity, and its more easy digestion ~
horse" saws he, "wiil take hours in eatine
stone Ia lbs. of hay, whereas he will ca
stone of steemcd potatoes in twenty MN
utes" A horse thus fed will therefore
ms ~ u than
fed in the common way; and it is probable
that the stomach being thus quickly satited
the animal will be disposed to sleep or rest
which is favorable to the digestive process
In letter from Mr.. Curwen to Mi. Peal
that gentleman observes. 81 can confirm AT
Ter the great and most extensive practice
every thing have formerly advanced will
respect to feeding horses on steamed pota
toes Ihave found it expedient to add a lit
tie more straw with view to render tn
food less costly. A decisive distinction
should be made between cut straw and chatf
in the husk or grain; the latter IS perfect
indigestible and dangerous / strongly sus
meet | have lost horses formerly by its bein!
used contrary to my orders. The practice
of potatoe feeding has been adopted by sev
eral gentlemen upon large scale, all O
whom concur in declaring that the oppos.
ton to the relinquishing of this mode o
feeding would now be as great as it was t
its adoption. / have found steamed straw
(cut) very good food when could do no bet
ter" Mr.. Curwen observes that horses fet
upon steamed potatoes should have but lit
tie water. and other writers say when horse
are fed principally on steamed potatoes the.
do not need any water.


"When there is no convenience for bruis
ing oats, much good may be done by mix
ing them with clover or other hay cut u
with small proportion of straw. BY this
two objects will be accomplished the oat
will be perfectly masticated, and, therefore
wholly converted to nutriment: and vast
OF hay will be prevented. Mr. Blaine, a
ENGLISH writer, thinks that three horse
NAV be supported in this way at as little e%
pense as two kept in the usual manner. Th
proportions lie recommends are one part ha'
TWO of straw, and one of oats; and Of tn
mixture he gives from three to six peel
daily, according TO the size and employmel
of the horse: and he observes that 1t Will az
very much to the nutriment, which tt
mixture affords, If the oats are previous
bruised. Mr.. White says, 81 am incline
TO think that clover hay is preferable for tn
purpose to any other. 1t is generally tho
that kind of hay is not well adapted for sa'
d1o-horses or such as are emDlOye ed in Quir

full articles.headline: NATURE OF SOILS.
full articles.article:
All sands are hot and dry--all clays cold
and wet; and, therefore, the manuring san
dy lands with clay, or clay lands with sand,
is best, for this changes the nature OF the
land itself; whereas dung, and other substan-
ces, afford only an inferior and temporary
improvement. Mixed soils, which incline
to the clayey kind, are best for corn and
pulse. But 1t is not the natural soil only
that the farmer ought to consider, but the
depth of il. and what is Immediately under
meath it. For if the richest soil is only Sc
ven o. eight inches deep, aud lies on a cold
wet clay or stone, it will not b. 50 fruitful as
leaner soils that lie on better under STRAIT
um. Gravel is, perhaps, the best under
stratum to make the land prolific.


The best loans, and natural earths, arc
of bright brown or hazely colaur. Hence,
they are called hazel leans. They cut
smooth and tolerahle easy, without ctiHginh
to the spade or plough share; are ,iTAt, III
able, and fall into small clods without cda ~
ping or cracking in dry weather ui turning
into mortar when wet. Dark grey, and rus
set mould, are accounted the next best
The VOL St of all arc the light and dark ash
colour. The goodness OF land may also be
very well judged of by the smell and touch.
The best emits a fresh pleasant scent On be-
us hNS " lSi'HSiNNl hPt NoINAlilll aitNt
rain; and being just proportion Of sand and
clay intimately blended, will not stick much
10 the fingers on handling But all soils,
however good may be impoverished, and e
ven worn ont, By successive crops without
rest, especially if the ploughings are not
very frequently repeated before the seed is
4 suwn.


| IT we examine tracts of land " ich have
not been cultivated, we find nature has adapt
ed different kinds of plants to most Of the
distnguishable varieties of SOILS; and altho'
some belonging TO one, may from some
cause or other be found on lands of differ
ent quality, they seldom thrive, or perfect
their seeds, so as to become general, The
great care OF the farmer ought, therefore,
to be, by proper niHtnrcs, 10 reduce his
land to that state and temperament IN which
the extremes of hot and cold, wet and dry
are best corrected By each other; to give
them every possible advantage flowing from,
the benign influence Of sun and air; to adopt
such plants as thev afford in this state thc
greatest nouriShment TO; and 10 renew thcil
fertility by q judicious allowance of the NOS,
proper manurcs. Where these things art
done, there are few spots 50 untiitndi; te
cultivation as not to repay his expeHs 5 and
laJour with plentlful increase. But y tNput
these, the best tracts of land will in time Gc-
come barren waste, or produce htt.t hui


weeds.

monty thought to be; but horses are general
ly fond of it, and if allowed, would often eat
too much. 1t is supposed that saccharIne
matter is developed by the fermentation
which hay undergoes in the NOW, and as
that which is NOW burnt appears to contain
more saccharine matter than any other, 1t is
probable that it may be found preferable
where used with discretion, provided it has
not been too much heated; for when it has
become quite brown there will generally be
found considerable degree of acidty in it,
which probably would be injurious if eaten
freely. Hay that is dry and void of smell is
certainly bad; but that which is dusty, moul-
dy. and of bad smell is exceedingly prelu-
dicial. Dry hay should be moistened with
water and if at all dusty, should be previous
iy we'll shaken: this is particularly neccs-
sary when it is used for horses that are gree
dy of water or subject to coughs.-Hay at
ter 1t is one year old, rather becomes worse
than improves, particularly in small mows /:
after the second year, it should never be used
when any that is newer can be procured
perhaps good straw is preferable to 1t, espe-
cially if the horse is allowed good quantl-
ty of oats. Horses should be allowed either


a run at grass or green food in the Stable
during the early part of summer

full articles.article:
FARM, Of about 65 acres situated in Millcreek
Hundred, Newcastle county, Del, about three
miles from Staunton, and eight from Whining
ton, of which about ten acres are wood land, and
the residue arabic, well set with orchard grass
and clover The Buildings are, good stone
dwelling house, 81 by "a feet, Two stories high,
gith three rooms on the first foor and four on
the second with good cellar under the whole
"a frame Barn, cellared under, 36by 80 feet
a Stone .Toiner's shop, and Comcrib, % by II
feet, and stone Smokc-house, all Of which are
nearly new and in good order. The quality
the land is well adapted for farming or grazing,
and has been well lined, it is in good neigh
bourhood, near several places ofpublc worship,
is in good neighbourhood for Mills, and within
two miles of good Limestone quarry. There is
likewise, a young thrifty Apple Orchard, and a
Peach Orchard, and the land is we'll watered
with good springs For further particulars en-
quire of JosrrH BRINGuuNsT, Wilmington, or on
the Farm, of JOHN FERRIS.

THE Subscriber takes this opportunity to in
form the public, that the establishment hereto
fore conducted by hneS Ray, Esq, together
with the accounts connected with the business
of that establishment from the first of January,
1926, have passed into his hands; and that he
will continue the business in all its branches, at
the Oh Stand, corner of Tatnall and Quecn-strs.
near the Friend Meeting House. where he will
manufacture, and furnish at Philadelphia prices,
Mould and D;m CINULES, FuHer's, TeElov aud

full articles.headline: Twenty Dollars Reward.
full articles.article:
Ran away from the subscriber, on Saturday, the
18th inst, an lndentcd boy to the Coachnaking
business, named JOHN HALL: he went in COM
pany with hoy bound to Thomas Moore. He
is about 10 years Of age, about FIVE feet six inches
high, thick set. speaks quick when spoken to-
has rather down look; light hair and light com
plexion-had on when he went way, a suit
blue clothes, fur hat, and boots


Whoever will secure the boy in any jail, so
that | can get him again, shall receive the above
reward, together with reasonable charges il
brought home. All persons are cautioned
against harboring said boy, at theirperl.


PETER A. HUMPHREYS.


Wilmington, Del. Jan. 25-l9 At.

numbers would have died.

full articles.headline:
THE FARMER.

From the New England Farmer.
ON THE MAN AG EMENT AND DIS


EASES OF HORSES.
full articles.article:
FxDerience has often demonstrated that
the most serious consequences may ensue
when horse is subjected to violent exer-
else ON full stomach. This indigestion
thus occasiened often causes violent chollcs
which sometimes prove fatal. Surgeon
White says" Il have known many instances
of this: and when we consider now often
post and stage-coach horses are suddenly at
tackled during their work with gripes OF
fret, as it is commonly termed, arising en-
tirely from this cause, it will appear aston
ishing that it has not excited the attention OF
post masters and other proprietors.


Oats, which escape being crushed or brok-
en- by the teeth, though properly soaked by
the saliva and Juice of the stomach, are not
properly digrsted. The following commu-
nication from an English officer in the SER
vice of the East India Company will sbew
the utility of brushing grain tor feeding
horses or cattle.


II have always been an advocate for cut
tinp hay and straw, and bruising corn (grain)
for cattle of every description, and am con-
yinced that any man, who has pad atten-
zion to the subject, will soon see the advant-
age that must result from the adoption of
that practice. My attention was partlcu-
lsrly called to this subject by circumstance
which came under my notice when with the
cavalry unQef Iluiu Lam, Oh VIZ "N'NN 80
banks of the Junna in 1904. Channa, the
usual food, being scantilysuppli ed, Lord
Like ordered the horses to be fed with
equal parts of channa and barley, bruised
and steeped in the usual way; but from the
irreyularity of the size of the barley and
ehanna. and nattention oil the part OF those,
whose duty it was to sec it prepared, the
greater part of the barley was given entire.
and passed through the stomach and lntes-
tines of the horses, apparently little, u al Az
IMPAIRED in it's nutrtive quality ne scar
citv of grain which prevailed at that time n
dnced MANY thousands to flock TO the Brat
isb camp. in search of food, and daily wit
ressed for many weeks together many hun
dreds of those people Of all ages; coming IN
TO the lines of our cavalry, and anxlously col
lecting and carrying away the excremeht as
Il fell from the horses. This they exposed
few hours to the sun, and by rubbing and
sitting it, procured a large supply of good
food. This detail, which is on son'e account
affecting to humanity will probably go fur
ther in convincing the incredulous upon this
.ubiect than the most ingenious theory. II
must prove to every unprejudiccd man that
a Drodigious waste takes place III the use o'
corn for horses when it is not previously
ground or bruised"


1t appears from the experience OF Mr.
Curwen a celebrated English agriculturist
that the feeding of working horses OF
cooked provender is highly profitable. One
great advantage, he observes is the shor
time that is required for eating prope,
quantity, and its more easy digestion ~
horse" saws he, "wiil take hours in eatine
stone Ia lbs. of hay, whereas he will ca
stone of steemcd potatoes in twenty MN
utes" A horse thus fed will therefore
ms ~ u than
fed in the common way; and it is probable
that the stomach being thus quickly satited
the animal will be disposed to sleep or rest
which is favorable to the digestive process
In letter from Mr.. Curwen to Mi. Peal
that gentleman observes. 81 can confirm AT
Ter the great and most extensive practice
every thing have formerly advanced will
respect to feeding horses on steamed pota
toes Ihave found it expedient to add a lit
tie more straw with view to render tn
food less costly. A decisive distinction
should be made between cut straw and chatf
in the husk or grain; the latter IS perfect
indigestible and dangerous / strongly sus
meet | have lost horses formerly by its bein!
used contrary to my orders. The practice
of potatoe feeding has been adopted by sev
eral gentlemen upon large scale, all O
whom concur in declaring that the oppos.
ton to the relinquishing of this mode o
feeding would now be as great as it was t
its adoption. / have found steamed straw
(cut) very good food when could do no bet
ter" Mr.. Curwen observes that horses fet
upon steamed potatoes should have but lit
tie water. and other writers say when horse
are fed principally on steamed potatoes the.
do not need any water.


"When there is no convenience for bruis
ing oats, much good may be done by mix
ing them with clover or other hay cut u
with small proportion of straw. BY this
two objects will be accomplished the oat
will be perfectly masticated, and, therefore
wholly converted to nutriment: and vast
OF hay will be prevented. Mr. Blaine, a
ENGLISH writer, thinks that three horse
NAV be supported in this way at as little e%
pense as two kept in the usual manner. Th
proportions lie recommends are one part ha'
TWO of straw, and one of oats; and Of tn
mixture he gives from three to six peel
daily, according TO the size and employmel
of the horse: and he observes that 1t Will az
very much to the nutriment, which tt
mixture affords, If the oats are previous
bruised. Mr.. White says, 81 am incline
TO think that clover hay is preferable for tn
purpose to any other. 1t is generally tho
that kind of hay is not well adapted for sa'
d1o-horses or such as are emDlOye ed in Quir
